U.S.S. COBIA (SS245) - Report of War Patrol
Number THREE.
(A) Subject Report.
(B) Track Chart.
Enclosures (A) and (B) covering the THIRD
War Patrol of this vessel during the period 30 November 1944 to.
24 January 1945, are forwarded herewith.

U.S.S. COBIA - Third War Patrol - report of.
5 November 1944
6 November 1944
8. 20 November 1944
29 November 1944
29 November 1944
A - PROLOGUE
Arrived Fremantle from Second War
Patrol.
Commenced rest period, and normal
refit by USS GRIFFIN and Division 122
Relief Crew.
Regular crew returned to ship.
Completed sound tests, deep dive,
practice approaches, battle surface
and firing of three exercise torpedoes.
Ready for soa.

Submerged and made practice approach.

Submerged.

Made radar contact, range, 3050, and lost it after

6 December 1944
0830
1847
2015

Submerged to approach Lombok undetected,
Surfaced. Used the SJ to make landfall by sweep-
ing ahead in hand three times every five minutes,
thus minimizing chances of detection.
Radar conact on land, range 56,000.
Commenced transit of Lombok.
Radar contact on small patrol boat close to Bali
shore. (Ship contact #2). He never changed course
to head toward us and never closed inside five miles.
Completed transit, no strain.
7 December 1944.
0206
Radar contact, range 6,900. (Ship contact #23).
Apparently one of the sailboats which are ever-
present here. Avoided.

Sighted sailboat. (Ship Contact #39).
1527
1529
1559.
1900
The two boats were converging on us so in order to
remain undetected while approaching Karimata, submerged.
Chlorine in both batteries. The amount of chlorine
emitted was small but battery water samples taken
showed this water to be saline. We had watered
batteries this morning. Electrolyte showed chlorine
by Silver Nitrate Test.
Not knowing how much chlorine was present decided
to accept slight loss in capacity and remove unmixed
water from cell tops. Commenced pumping water from
cell tops. Blew all water from battery water tanks
to ship's tanks.
Surfaced. Headed into sea at one third speed so as
to minimize motion and mixing of electrolyte.
9 December 1944
0135
Completed pumping contaminated water from sell tops.
Charged battery.

9 December 1944 (Con't)
0615
1900
Submerged. Spent day investigating reasons for
chlorination. Reason - Improper procedure and tes-
ting by inexperienced personnel. Improper supervision.
Surfaced. Commenced transit of Karimata Strait.
10 December 1944
0313
0446
1308
1500
Made radar contact on Soroetoe Island range 70,000
yds. Received orders to be on station December 11.
We can't make it. Decided not to send dispatch in
Karimata for reasons of security.
Completed transmit of Parimata. Proceeding to sta-
tion at full speed.
Pighted on iki -sland bearing 35701, then Datoe
Island bearing 047°T.
Took pictures of Pengiki Island at 5 miles distance.
No signs of life visible.

but could not raise anyone. Gave it up as a bad
job. See Section L.
Radar contact (Ship Contact #10). He was a U.S.
Submarine, from his 5J interference, and probably
the Pargo but he didn't answer our challenge.
Sighted DAVE, distance 10 miles. (Aircraft Contact
#2). Submerged.
Surfaced.

report of. (Con'td)
Arrived at point assigned us during present operations.
'Surfaced. Patrolled line between Balabac Island
and mainland of Borneo.
Radar contact, range 12,800. (Ship Contact #11).
Tracked him. in to 5,000 yds. and his escort to 4,300.
He was on straight course speed 8 1/2. Identified
by sighting against intermittent lightning flashes
as a small sea truck with a sampan escort, both too
small for torpedoes. Let him go in hopes that he
was blazing trail for some larger customers.
13 December 1944
0020
0557
1843
Lost radar contact at 14,000 yds.
Submerged.

0600

a closer patrol of Balabac Strait.
Surfaced close abroad Cape Melville on Balabac Island.

0137
0236
1216
1235
1916
Sighted flares or explosions to the south. Headed
toward at full speed until definitely ascertained
that they were over land. Probably our planes
bombing Borneo.
Received orders to change stations. Headed for new
station at full speed.
Sighted plane. (Aircraft Contact 4)
Submerged.
Surfaced.
Broke despatch rearrainging patrol line when
within five miles of new station service. Commenced
surface patrol.

3. January 1945

1845
Officer of the Deck and lookout sighted what may have
been a periscope while we were five miles south of Balabac
Island. It was bright moonlight and there was much debris
floating around, so the contact was doubtful and never
verified by the sound watch. Cleared area at flank speed
for twenty minutes.
Submerged.
Surfaced. Decided to head toward area between Balabac
Strait and Dangerous Ground to see if anything were
heading north toward Palawan Passage.

Conducted surface patrol off entrance to Balabac Strait.

Third War Patrol. report of. (Cont'd):
At approximate position assigned for search. Made a
trim dive.
Surfaced and patrolled assigned point. During the time
between surfacing and daybreak made our sweeps with the
SJ in three minute intervals so that it wouldn't be
detected,
Headed on course 023 at 10 knots in scouting line with
BESUGO and HARDHEAD.
Sighted floating mine and tried to sink it with gun fire.
20 mm hits only dented it.
1500
Changed course south.
1605
1915
2000
Sighted another floating mine.
Arrived at patrol point and commenced patrolling in
conjunction with BESUGO and HARDHEAD, in courses 113-293,
normal to expected course of enemy.

1357

One hit under his bridge. The first must havo hit a
magazine or boiler because a huge cloud of smoke arose
and he was knocked in half.
Target sank bow first with his screws still turning
over in the air. Hurried look showed all clear.
Surfaced to sec if wo could got a picture.
Plane close aboard our starboard bow (Air Craft Contact
#2321). Submerged.

He dropped his bomb as we arrived at 100 feet. The DCI
read below, port, aft so that he was either carrying a
depth charge or the reading was a bounce off the bottom.
We were in 30 fathoms.
Sighted plane (Aircraft Contact #2322). Went to 100 feet
for a half hour.
Surfaced.
Headed for Karimata. Not enough fuel for an end around
so decided to go home.
Converted #3 and #235 to Main Ballast Tanks.

same one we sighted on the 9th.

Surfaced and headed through Lombok at flank speed.
Sighted a small patrol boat (Ship Contact #23 14) range
3300 yards. Turned away to avoid, but he sighted us
with a range of 2900 yards when on our quarter. H
fired a few small caliber shots, none close, before we
out-distanced him and cleared the strait.
Passed an unidentified U.S. Sub headed north through
strait. Exchanged recognition signals but not calls.
(Ship Contact #15).

18:
U. S. S. COBIA - Third War Patrol - report of. (Cont'd)
C - WEATHER
In Balabac Strait we had calm clear weather with frequent
showers.
Northwest of Palawan there were also occasional showers,
and the edge of a typhoon produced some moderately heavy sea.
Raincoats were a constant necessity though other warm clothes
were not used.
D - TIDAL INFORMATION
Consistent currents as follows were encountered:
3 knots to south in Lombok Strait, December 6.
I knot to east through Java Sea, December 7-9%; also January
17-18.
1.0 to 1.5 knots at 0750 through Balabac Strait, December
12-15 and December 24-27.
.3 to .6 knots to northeast and northwest off Northeast
Dangerous Ground, December 16-20.
A Jap raft was seen at 1930, 9 January in Lat. 5°58' Long.
106°47' it was later on (15 Jan. at 0930) seen at Lat. 4°34'
Long. 105°15'. A set of 226°, drift .94 knots.
E-NAVIGATIONAL AIDS
Cape Melville: Light on south end of Balabac Island was
used consistently for daytime fixes. No lighted navigational
aids were sighted.
While in Dangerous Ground took soundings every fifteen min-
utes as we passed over a lot of area which showed infrequent or
no soundings. This is being forwarded to the Hydrographic Office.
HYDRO
1-XTRA'

U.S.S. COBIA - Third War Patrol - report of. (Cont'd)
H. ATTACK DATA (Torpedo Attack Report Form)
Time 13-52-28H Date January 14, 1945 Lat. 5-51N Long. 103-16E
Target Data - Damage Inflicted
Description
Ships Sunk
Single CM similar to coastal mine layers in ONI 41-42%3
about 700 tons
Mast sighted bearing 1880T, distance about 30,000
yards in good visibility on surface. Turn count:
210 RPM - 11 knots.
One coastal mine layer about 700 tons.
Ships Damaged None.
Damage Deter- Saw ship sink with 300 down angle and screws still
mined by
turning in the air.
Target Draft 6' 1" Course 350 Speed 11 Range 1180 yards.
Own Ship Data
Speed 2 Course 280 Depth 64' Angle 1° down (at firing).
Fire Control and Torpedo Data
Type Attack
Sighted mast at 1880T hull down. Submerged and
headed toward. First submerged look showed a 30°
port angla on the bow, the next à 30° starboard
angle. Subsequent looks showed radical zigs but
a base course of roughly 350° which would pass
close enough for a good shot. Apparently he was
either heading north to rendezvous with a convoy
or, as the presence of a plane later suggested,
he may have been on a sub hunt. Mide ro ay all
tubes as he is the only shot we have had this run
and I don't want to let him get away. With 8
left gyros and a 1200 run fired the first of five
bow tubes.
53 seconds after firing the first fish hit with
a loud explosion, so held fire on the sixth
torpedo.
.

26:
· U.S.S. COBIA - Third War Patrol - report of.
I. MINES
DP-30-3M.
Floating mines were seen off the Malay Peninsula around
Lat. 5N; Long. 105. These were spherical, horned and they
floated with about 1/5 of the mine above water.
J. ANTI SUBMARINE MEASURES
10TH FLT
DESLANT.
No anti-submarine measures were encountered in balabac
Strait.
The CM sunk on January 14 was echo ranging but he never
showed any sign of having known of our presence. His turn count
was 210 RPM for 11 knots.
A consistent air patrol was encountered off Great Redang
Island. On the days of the U,. carrier strikes these were not
present.
K. MAJOR DEFECTS
Ј
BUSHIPS'
1. BATTERIES-On December 8, while proceeding to station, both
batteries were watered with water containing salt. While the
battery was on float there was no indication of chlorine. About
two hours after completion of watering we dove (1500) and im-
mediately noticed a smell of chlorine in the boat. The concen-
tration was not severe enough to cause discomfort. A silver ni-
trate test showed chloride ions present in the electrolyte in
both batteries. We stayed down about two more hours and used
the time to rig pumps to remove the contaminated electrolyte.
Fortunately there had been very little mixing of the con-
taminated water and the electrolyte and by pumping the level
down to -16 (two points below the average height before watering)
it was possible to remove most of the salt.
-s soon as the pumping was completed about a six hour job)
the batteries were put on charge and in about two hours there was
no more indication of chlorine in the battery exhaust. The
charge was continued and we equalized for two hours. The volt-
age was normal and there were no indications of weak individual
cells. The gravity, because of removal of electrolyte was lo-
wered about 9 points. After watering and charging and for the
patrol the equalizing gravity was about 10 points lower than
before removing the electrolyte.
The cause of the casualty was determined to be: 1, the
production of unacceptable battery water at the stills and fail-
ure of personnel to blow it to fresh water tanks instead of
battery water tanks, and 2, failure of electricians mates to run
sufficient water through the system before watering to test the
new water in the tanks. The roadings they got were on old water
in the de-ionizers.
recur.
Steps have been taken to insure that the casualty cannot
CONFIDENTIAL
-25-
5-XTRA-
26
27:
U.S.S. COBIA - Third War Patrol
report of.
K. MAJOR DEFECTS Cont'd.
J
BUSHIPS.
2. H.P. COMPRESSOR - #31 HP air compressor had to be completely over-
hauled half-way through the run, due to piston rings freezing and
breaking in all stages. Putting it out of commission for two days.
The probable cause is the irregular shape of the linors which
need renewing. Dospito the fact that all rings had been renewed on
last refit those that wore not broken were badly worn.
The compressor noods now liners and a complete check for align-
ment as it had given difficulty since commissioning.
3. ACCUMULATOR - HP air line from Air Flask to accumulator of Hy-
draulic system developed a look at the accumulator base. The hole
was near the bulkhoad making silvor soldering a difficult job as
the pipe had silver soldered joints and could not be removed to
gain access to the trouble.
It is recommended that HP fittings be installed on this pipe
to facilitate any repairs to the line.
4. TORPEDOES - Cobia carried a full load of Mk 23 torpedoes of
which about 1/3 had leaky charging check valves. Some of these
leaks were stopped by replacing the leather washer with a nylon
one. The rest could not be repaired.
Porformance of the five torpedoes fired was good, all ran
hot, straight and normal.
5. VAPOR COMPRESSION STILLS - After 180 hours of operation it be-
came necessary to dismantle #32 vapor compression still because the
readings on the water produced ran over the maximum on the scale
on the Kleinschmidt tester. Three small leaks in the coils were
silver soldered and the unit reassembled and rewired after which
it operated satisfactorily.
6. AUXILIARY ENGINE - After a total of 1187 hours of operation a
valve stem on #23 unit of the Auxiliary Engine snapped about 2"
from the valve. The valve was ground up and expelled and no
pieces remained. It was necessary to renew the head which was
dented, the injoctor which had a mashod tip, and tho romaining
throo valvos which wore bent.

28:
U. S. S. COBIA - Third War Patrol - report of.
L. RADIO
NRL
CRD.
Reception of the BAKER schedule was good throughout patrol.
It was noticed that VIXO was weaker during daylight than at night,
and had a very slight constant drift at all times. However, no
serials were missed.
good.
WOPACO reception and transmission, CW and voice, were very
Transmissions on the ship to shore frequencies were cleared
only after long periods of call-ups. On 11 December, tried for
1 hours to send a dispatch to CTF 71, without success. 16940 was
jammed, 12705 was in use, and VIXO could not be raised on 8470 or
4235. All our later transmissions went through satisfactorily.
12705 proved by far the best frequency and 16940 the most jammed
on all occassions.
There was no satisfactory test of VHF equipment.
Transmissions
were attempted to friendly subs encountered without reply. They
probably were not guarding VHF. Tried to raise a U.S. Liberator
off Balabac on 29 December, but he did not answer up.
Chungking's broadcasts were heavily jammed by three Jap
stations during the early part of the patrol. About 23 December, rec-
eption on 4155 improved greatly. Chungking station serials received
were as follows:
329, 330, 331, 332, 338, 341, 342, 344, 345, 346, 349, 355, 356;
357, 368, 369, 376, 387, 388, 391, 392; 395, 396, 397, 399, 400,
419, 420, 421, 423, 424, 425, 427, 429, 430.

GENERAL
report of.
M
we
RADAR
SD - RADAR
NRL'
CRD'
The SD performance was good. The method of keying the SD seems
quite effective. Our SD was keyed during the day only when the sky
was very overcast.
TROUBLES
Few troubles were encountered. Aside from the following,
enumerated casualties the only other troubles were jumpy supply volt-
ages which acted to mistune the SD:
Physical Casualties:
1- Broken connection in the transmitter tube cathode circuit.
Trouble indication was transmitter tube current very low for
very high transmitter plate voltage.Connection was repaired
and operation again normal.
2- Keying switch not making contact, faulty switch. Keying
switch replaced and operation again normal.
3- Bad local oscillator tube (V205-9002). Indication: scope
grass level abonormally jumpy. V205 replaced and operation
normal.

APR RADAR REPORT
GENERAL
Jap radar activity seemed very negligeble during this patrol.
The performance of the APR was quite good, and with the new location
ef the APR units in the Control Room a very efficient system for
the APR watch was carried out.
TROUBLES
1- Due to constant use of the APR, one set of gears in the re-
ceiver dial gear train was quite worn and several times the dial
.knot stuck. This was remedied by training the two parts of the
split gear 180° in relation to each other.
2- Hetrodyning oscillator tube (V108-6A07) was burned out.
Trouble was characterized by the lack of a steady whistle when the
hetrodyning switch was turned on. V108-6A07 was replaced and cond-
itions are normal.
OPERATION
Very few Jap frequencies were detected.

SJ INTERFERENCE AND JAMMING
There was no jamming of the SJ encountered during this patrol.
The intereference noted on the SJ was only from other SJ radars
aboard friendly submarines,
All showed railings on the A Scope and 20° wide interfer-
ence patterns on the PPI.

2-XTRA.
-34-
35
36:
U.S.S. COBIA - Third War Patrol repot of.
N. SOUND
Only sound contact was the CM mentioned earlier in this re-
port. His echo ranging was first picked up at 9000 yards on the
"QB". His screws were not heard until the range reached 4000
yards. Sound conditions were fair to poor due to shallow water
and shore noises. The Limit Switch on the "QB" failed to operate
due to heavy arcing of the contacts. Now parts wore installed and
no further trouble developed.
0. DENSITY LAYERS
Most of the patrol was conducted in the western approachos
to Balabac Strait and good gradients were available. During per-
iods of quiet weather the surface temperature varied between 68
and 84 degrees F. After prolonged periods of quiet weather the
surface temperature roso and good, sharp 6 degree gradients de-
veloped between 60 and 120 foot and the line generally continued.
in a gradual curvo to the tost depth. However, when mixing occurr-
od after a blow, the surface isothermal water became lower in
temperature and showed no change to 150 foot.
We spent about a wook in rough water off the northeast corner
of the dangerous round. Under 200 foot there wore good sharp
negative gradients of 5-6 degrees and continuing to tost depth.
Abovo 200 foot the water was strictly isothermal.
The last part of the patrol was conducted in smooth water off
the Malay Ponisula and no gradients wore observed down to 200 foot.
CONFIDENTIAL
HYDRO
1-XTRA.
-35-
36
37:
U.S.S. COBIA - Third War Patrol - report of.
P. HEALTH, FOOD, AND HABITABILITY
We had three cases of mumps, one of appendicitis, one of gonno-
rhea, a pilonidal oyst caso, and two dehydrated Korean survivors, one
severely, during this patrol.
Twenty two days after the start of the patrol, ono man reported
swelling in his loft parotid gland, dryness in his throat, nausea and
illness. Ho, was diagnosed as having mumps, and was isolated in the
after corner of the After Battory. Fiftoon mon aboard had not had
mumps and those were shifted the farthest away from the isolated corner.
After 13 days of treatment and isolation, during which tho discaso
did not dovolop complications, the patient was cured.
On this same 13th day a second man, who had previously had mumps,
bilateral, reported a swelling of his jaw. Ho had had trouble with
his wisdom tooth and it was hoped that it wore this rather than mumps.
Four days lator the swolling had subsided and apparently ho was clear.
Iowover 10 days later, his testicles bogan swolling and ho was turned
in. The same day a third patient reported swollon testicles and was
turned in. Those two remained in bod until the end of the patrol.
An appendicitis caso devolopod 40 days after the patrol started.
Icc packs and dict cured the attack in 4 days.
A wock after the start of the patrol ono cook reported gonnorhoa.
Penicillin treatment was given and the patient returned to duty after
1 days.
Ono man reported severe pain in a pilonidal cyst. The cyst was
lanced with excellent results and the man returned to duty aftor
› days.
One of two Korean survivors picked up was in a soverc state of
lehydration. Ho craved water and had to bo forcibly kopt in a bunk
for the first two days and provented from gorging himself with it.
1 solution of doxtrose as well as increasing rations of wator has
alleviated his condition.
The food this patrol was the best we have had thus far. This is
a direct result of carrying a large store of frozen foods and of a
dccrcased amount of spoilage.
Habitability was cxccllont in normal running conditions. It is
believed that an additional air conditioning coil in the aftor part of
the Forward Battery would help the habitability of the forward part
of the ship considerably.
Armed forces phonograph records and a good supply of other records
word in constant uso. Movics in the Forward Torpedo Room wcrc a
source of rocrcation cach Sunday and Wednesday afternoons.

J.S:S. COBIA- Third War Partol - Report of.
Q. PERSONNEL
Unless a regular system of classes is initiated only the
more enterprising will attempt to qualify. The freezing of rates
of unqualified men, giving qualified men the desiriable billets re-
gardless of seniority, and giving qualified men a choice of staying
in or making the next patrol has done its part towards pushing
qualification. Unqualified officers hold class daily with an
average of ten men to a class; qualified men demonstrate a piece
of machinery to a group of 3 or 4 daily. In this way the unquali-
fied man is given upward of two hours concertrated instruction
daily and unqualified officers must go deeply into a system before
they can explain it. Men received aboard qualified on other boats
go through the same routine as unqualified men except that they
are not required to fill out a notebook.
The younger men we have recieved, both in our commissioning
allowance and since, have developed suprisingly well. In
several cases they have proven more valuable than the more ex-
perienced older men. At first, these men, many just out of
service schools, were barely if at all able to hold their rates.
With some sea experience to fill the knowledge they were given
in schools they have gradually turned out well and numerous of
them have been advanced.
The lookout competition each patrol has been a tremendous
factor in keeping the lookouts alert. The prestige of the winner
as well as his prize gives him as enviable position among the
crew of the boat. Conversely, those who constantly miss things
in their sectors are chided for their inefficency by their
shipmates.
Nobody on the ship has been transferred to relief crews
without being qualified. or disqualified. At the end of a run those
qualified men who the head of department feels have done the best
work are given their choice of a transfer or another run. Though
it ocasionaly envolves transferring a fiew of the men it would be
desirable to keep, the system acts as a reward for good work and
as a stimulus for it.

U RADAR COUNTER-MEASURES
V REMARKS
The Loran Equipment was used to check the ship's position
between 15° South and the South China Sea. In all cases the
fixes obtained corresponded with the ship's position and it was
a useful check in bad weather. However the stations available
had lines so nearly parallel that Loran was not used as the
ship's fundamental navigation. With the establishment of stations
in the Philippines it is believed that Loran could be used
exclusively in this area, though not at the present time.

SUBMARINE SQUADRON EIGHTEEN
Care of Fleet Post Office,
San Francisco, California.
24 January 1945.
The Commander Submarine Squadron EIGHTEEN.
The Commander-in-Chief, UNITED STATES FLEET.
(1) The Commander Submarines, SEVENTH FLEET.
(2) The Commander SEVENTH FLEET.
U.S.S. COBIA (SS245) - Report of Third War Patrol.
This third war patrol of the GOBIA was conducted in the
SOUTH CHINA SEA. Only one contact was made on a target worth torpedo
expenditure and this was successfully attacked.
2.
Attack #1 on 14 January 1945 was a day periscope attack
on a coastal mine layer proceeding independently. Five torpedoes were
fired from range 1180 Yards, 105° truck, small gyros and 4' depth setting.
One torpedo hit and sank the target. The COBIA surfaced to take a tempting
photograph of the sinking ship and was rewarded with an aircraft bomb as
she dived to avoid. No damage was sustained.
3.
Two prisoners were brought back, taken from a raft on which
they claimed to have been adrift for forty days. Three cases of mumps, one
case of appendicitis and several other ailments, plus the condition of the
prisoners kept the pharmacist mate busy. He is to be congratulated for the
measures he took which prevented an epidemic of mumps.
4.
The COBIA returned in good material condition. A normal refit
by USS EURYALE and Submarine Division 182-2 relief crew should correct all
deficiencies noted.
5.
Chlorine in the main battery was experienced in the Java Sea
enroute to station. This was caused by watering with water above allowable
saline content. This casualty although nullified by the excellent remedial
treatment given the battory, emphasises the necessity for utmost vigilance
on the part of operating personnel at all times.
6.
The state of morale, training, and cleanliness upon return
from patrol was extremely high.
7.
The squadron commander congratulates the commanding officer,
officers and crow on the damage inflicted on the onomy. The COBIA sank the
onc target encountered, which is all that can be expected of any submarine.
STANLEY P. MOSELEY.

2 February 1945.
The Commander Submarines, SEVENTH FLEET.
The Commander in Chief, UNITED STATES FLEET.
The Commander, SEVENTH FLEET.
U.S.S. COBIA (55245) - Report of Third War
Patrol - Comment on.
The Third War Patrol of the COBIA, under the command
of Commander A. L. BECKER, U.S.N., was conducted in the areas of the
SOUTH CHINA SEA.
2.
The only attack of the patrol took place on 14 January
when a daylight submerged attack was made on a vessel which was
identified as similar to a coastal mine layer. Five torpedoes were
fired from an excellent position with torpedo run 1200 yards. The
sixth torpedo was ready but was withheld when the first hit was heard
prior to its being fired. The target was seen to blow up and sink.
3.
From 12 December to 8 January COBIA performed
reconnaissance duty off BALABAC STRAIT and in the area south of
DANGEROUS GROUND.
4.
The award of the Submarine Combat Insignia is
authorized for this patrol.
5.
The Force Commander congratulates the Commanding
Officer, Officers and Crew of the COBIA on this successful patrol
during which valuable reconnaissance duty was performed and the
following damage was inflicted upon the enemy:
SUNK
1 CM (EU)
700 Tons.
JAMES FIFE.
